Award.AwardTitle: Questions on Algebraic Operads and Related Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Operads and their generalizations are used to describe a large class of algebraic structures. They play an important role in the study of various geometric objects, in tackling foundational questions of quantum mechanics, and in addressing certain questions in number theory. This research project aims to resolve important open questions in this area. In addition to pursuing the research project, the investigator will advise graduate student research projects and expects to supervise undergraduate research projects as well. Jointly with coauthors, the investigator is writing a graduate level textbook on deformation quantization of symplectic manifolds.

The principal investigator is tackling the Deligne-Drinfeld conjecture on the Grothendieck-Teichmueller Lie algebra using the deformation complex of the operad governing Gerstenhaber algebras and Kontsevich's graph complex related to deformation quantization. The PI is working on a circle of problems related to the modular operad which is obtained by applying the Feynman transform to the operad governing commutative algebras. The PI also works on the problem of deformation quantization over a graded base and studies a higher categorical structure on homotopy algebras. The study of the Grothendieck-Teichmueller Lie algebra is motivated by its links to deformation quantization, the absolute Galois group of rational numbers and the theory of motives. Questions about the Feynman transform of the operad governing commutative algebras are motivated by the study of spaces of long knots.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
The support from DMS 1501001 resulted in several high profile publications on algebraic operads and formality theorems. During the term of the grant, two PhD students defended their dissertations: Elif Altinay-Ozasal defended her thesis "Deformation quantization over a Z-graded base" and graduated from Temple University in the summer of 2017; Geoffrey Schneider defended his thesis "Recursively generating formality quasi-isomorphisms with applications to deformation quantization" and graduated from Temple University in the spring of 2017.  A software package for computing a formality quasi-isomorphism for the operad governing brace algebras was successfully developed. 

During the term of the grant, the PI worked on research projects with 3 undergraduate students. One of this project resulted in a beta version of a software package for the so-called GT-shadows. Another project was devoted to developing a software package for testing Joan Birman's conjecture on a graph complex related to finite type invariants of knots. 

The PI ran research oriented graduate seminars and one undergraduate (reading) seminar. In March of 2018, the PI gave a plenary talk at the conference "Higher Structures 2" which was held at the University of Pennsylvania in honor of Murray Gerstenhaber and Jim Stasheff. In August of 2017, the PI gave a plenary talk at the conference "Geometry and Physics" which was held at the Penn State University.  In October of 2016, the PI gave a plenary talk at the conference "Cyclic Homology", which was held in Warsaw, Poland. In March of 2016, the PI gave a plenary talk at the Closing Conference for the Programon Higher Structures in Geometry and Physics. This program took place at the Max-Planck institute in Bonn, Germany.


Last Modified: 10/05/2018
Modified by: Vasiliy A Dolgushev
